B00006IUIG|5.0|In 8 1/2 we enter the fragmented world belonging to a filmmaker struggling with the creation of his next film.  Guido Anselmi is the protagonist and is a thinly-veiled projection of (director) Federico Fellini.  Formally, this film has moments of rare beauty.  In terms of content, it is a confessional piece that appears extremely personal while at the same time giving voice to common struggles of man.  Guido is subjected to a maelstrom of questions which he has no answers to.  One can assume these are all questions that he is silently asking himself.  Guido's conversations become quite loaded and reveal an incomplete man beneath the mystique of an artistic reputation.  Guido navigates often hostile environments with only brief possibilities for fulfillment and repose.  Guido cannot find the worldly rewards that he expects for himself and seems as much a victim of his own pessimism as of the endless demands of his colleages and lovers.  Toward the end, the desperation featured in the story might actually reflect the reality of the production of 8 1/2.  I am only guessing, because as obsurd as the film becomes it seems to remain interested in \\"the truth\\" of things.  Questions play a large role in this story as much as do the silences that often follow them.  <br />Fellini has left us with a groundbreaking film that has a lot of heart.  I highly recommend this DVD to anyone willing to watch it.

0393312836|5.0|If you have only seen the Stanley Kubrik film &quot;A Clockwork Orange&quot;, you really must read the book.  The movie only shows the first twenty chapters.  While the movie is well done, it does not tell the whole story.  In most copies of the book, all twenty-one chapters are present.  Both the movie and the book are a very insightful and alaramingly realistic satire of modern day adolescents.  What Anthony Burgess wrote in 1962 seems very realistic today.<br />While the coded language or slang used by Burgess is often hard to decode, it gets easier as you read further into the book.  Alex is a rebellous and often violent teenager.  With his gang of thugs, he rules the night with violence and theft.  The crime spree continues until Alex is arrested and convicted of murder.  At this point, we see a megalomanical government attempt to intervene by committing what we might now call a human rights violation.  Through a series of dramatic episodes, classic conditioning cures Alex of his violent tendencies.  Alex is then released into a world he is forced to rediscovered.  Many of the things he once found pleasurable are now painful.  These events nearly cause Alex's demise.  It is only through his near death that the conditioning is reversed and his mind is liberated.  With a free mind, Alex is left with the prospect of finally having to act as an adult and take on adult responsibilities.<br />The controlling government is eerily reminiscent of books such as &quot;1984&quot; and &quot;Brave New World&quot;.  If you enjoyed these books or books similar to these, I suspect you would enjoy reading &quot;A Clockwork Orange&quot;.  Even if you personally find the book unreadable, you will at least learn what a &quot;clockwork orange&quot;, the name means.
B000005H3A|5.0|Jazz can be a very personal or subjective form of music.  To me Takin' Off  by Herbie Hancock is one of the best examples of early 1960's music.  Other jazz classics of this time period are generally driven by the trumpet and alto sax. Takin' Off features  no less than Freddie Hubbard, Dexter Gordon, Butch Warren, and Billy Higgins.  But it is Hancock who is in charge of tempo and mood.<br />The result is an album of grace, character and soul.  Watermelon Man, Empty Pockets and Driftin' are Hancock classics but all six original songs and the three alternate takes are first rate.<br />All of this was done by Hancock at age 22.  No wonder he was able to easily move on to other, more understated  forms of Jazz so easily (Maiden Voyage).<br />Takin' Off is very underrated and a worthy addition to any collection.

B0000AZJXQ|5.0|A Perfect Circle's first cd is one of my all time favorites, so when this came out I had to get it. After tons of listens I've decided that Thirteenth Step, while a bit different, is just as good as their debut in its own right. Unlike their first, Thirteenth Step has a couple of filler-esk tracks in Crimes and Lullaby but these don't do much to pull down the greatness of the rest of this cd. The rest of this cd is just pure rockin' music with a sound that's not heard enough in todays rock music. It's slightly different from their first cd, with perhaps a more layered sound that has not quite as hard of an edge as their first effort, perhaps a little closer to Tool. Still it manages to be every bit as good, with great songs like Weak and Powerless (the solid single), The Noose (the instant APC classic), A Stranger (the very underrated mellow side of the cd), The Outsider (my favorite on the cd), The Nurse Who Loved Me (A great cover that shows just how much depth this band has), and Pet (one of their most rocking songs). With great songs like those this cd assured APC the title of my favorite band. This is not a cd you want to pass up. If you're a fan of any type of rock music this should be exactly what you're looking for. Be sure to check out their first cd if you haven't yet, as it is excellent.

B00018TI5E|5.0|So you're a fan of John's work with the Peppers, but his previous solo outings ... didn't sound very good? Shoddy sound quality? Well here finally is the definitive Frusciante album that you won't be embarrassed to play in front of family and friends. 5 stars for the production quality, 5 stars for the music. John divides his time between acoustic guitar, clean electric guitar and keyboard sounds. Together with Flea's bass and Chad's drums, there is a rich variety of textures on this album.<br />Going track by track: \\"Water,\\" \\"Second Walk\\" (stunning melodies on this track) and \\"This Cold\\" will have you up and dancing in seconds. \\"Carvel\\" rocks hard. \\"Song to Sing When I'm Lonely,\\" \\"Wednesday's Song,\\" \\"Omission\\" and \\"Chances\\" are all very beautiful songs. John's singing on Chances is his best ever; in fact his singing on the whole album is leaps and bounds ahead of his previous work. \\"Failure 33\\", \\"23 Go\\" and \\"Ghost 27\\" are a collection of strange and mesmerising sounds that thankfully don't detract from the quality of the album. The remaining vocal tracks, like the poignant \\"The Slaughter\\" and the haunting \\"Cut Out\\" are gems too. Suffice to say there isn't any filler on this album, every track having its merits.<br />Chad Smith's drumming is stellar throughout, definitely on par with anything he has ever done with the Peppers. Water has a nice bouncy bassline for Flea fans, but for the most part he plays low-key lines and allows John to shine. John's earlier solo albums may have been optional hearing for Peppers fans, but this is truly essential. Give it a few listens - you might be surprised to discover that \\"Shadows\\" has more replayability than \\"By the Way,\\" a quality that might not be apparent on your first hearing.

0385512104|5.0|Helps us to Understand Behavior of those with Autism<BR>This story opens with Christopher, a 15-year-old boy with a mild form of autism, discovering a neighbor's dog impaled on a garden fork. When the neighbor accuses him of murdering her dog, followed by a subsequent run-in with the police, Christopher takes it upon himself to solve the mystery of the dog's murder, and to write a book about the incident in the process. The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time is Christopher's account of his investigation, written from his first hand point of view. In the process he discovers some strange twists of events that directly affect his own life. The author of this book decided to pen this from Christopher's point-of-view. It is a fascinating look at what is going on in the mind of an autistic child. Actions that the boy takes may seem insane to an outsider, but are explained in a very logical manner by Christopher. Reading books like this, such as Motherless Brooklyn which is told from the point of view of a man with Tourette's Syndrome, really help to bring some sort of understanding to those of us who may be put off by the seemingly strange behavior of a person suffering from these types of afflictions. In addition to understanding Christopher's thought patterns, the story he is telling about his investigation is quite interesting. This is a short book and well worth the time. Another short novel I recommend is The Losers' Club by Richard Perez
B0000C7PRY|5.0|I have owned this album since the day it was released, and I would argue to anyone that this is Neal's finest work yet.  I was a big fan of Snow, and still am, but I would have to admit that it was very popish sounding.  This opus has brought back the true prog side of Neal, though it still maintains the continuity that was in Snow.  As you probably know, this is a two hour long concept album of what shaped Neal into the man that he is today.  It is about his struggles, his pain, his sorrow, and eventually the tremendous joy that overcame him when he turned his life over to the Lord.  I marvel at the people who say that they are fans of Neal, but then say that this album is lame.  This album IS Neal.  As far a music, the style of this album is very similar to the old spocks beard.  I am going to assume that you know what his style is, because this one is harder to get your hands on than anything by SB.  Lets just say though, that the hammond is still soaring and that he has now employed a live string section.  He also still uses french horn and sax.<br />I would like now to comment on his voice.  I have always felt that he is an amazing singer, but that he lacked slightly in passion and emotion.  This album shocked me as far as the emotion that he can put into his voice.  It is apparent that he truely believes in his message now, and has accepted who he is.  Way to go Neal!

His take on Dylan's &quot;I Shall Be Released&quot;, and &quot;Just Like A Woman&quot; are some of the most gut wrenching, and emotional versions of these songs ever waxed.  At the time of it's release 35 years ago, rock and soul had never been blended, with such power and grace.  Jimmy Page and Stevie Winwood along with B.J Wilson and long time Cocker keyboard man Chris Stainton, were all part of the supporting cast, that helped this album become a huge hit, that propelled Joe Cocker to rock stardom, that continues to this day, some 35 years later.

Of the entire PT catalogue, this album was the best laid out, most well written, it's as if it's one very long song. the cd starts out with the title track &quot;Lightbulb Sun&quot;, a quiet acoustic guitar and some angelic vocals, but suddenly you get the feeling your a part of something great when the band eplodes in from behind and takes over the rest of the track. a deep, dark, soothing song, gets you in the mood for more. Great lyrics accompanied with killer guitars. And finally &quot;Feel So Low&quot;, which pretty much summerizes the entire mood of the album. One of the last things you hear is Steven Wilson utter the word &quot;thanks&quot;, but who exactly is he thanking? Listen to this album to find out. You won't be dissapointed! 5 stars!!!
B00014TJ6Q|5.0|The rerelease of several &quot;middle period&quot; George Harrison albums is welcome news to both Beatles fans and pop/rock music fans in general. All of the albums that have now been made available on CD contain many songs worth reacquainting oneself with or discovering for the first time. But I think this album represents his best effort in this period and it, like much of his work, is terribly underrated. &quot;Love Comes to Everyone&quot; would have been right at home on &quot;Rubber Soul&quot;, and there are several other cuts on this CD that display gracefully the familiar mixture of sweetness, melodicism, and that distinctive guitar sound that constitute Harrison's style at its best.<br />Perhaps it is a blessing that so many of these albums have been unavailable for such a long time on CD. If any artist deserves a reevaluation, it's Harrison, who always seems vulnerable to the invidious comparison: he's good but he is no Lennon or McCartney. While there is truth in that, there is also truth in the fact that too much of his work has been dismissed all too easily. If he is no John or Paul, he nonetheless is a superb craftsman and song writer who just happened to find himself always in the shadows of his legendary bandmates. Maybe now with so much time having passed since the Beatles and with the lack of familiarity with the newly rereleased material that its absence has caused, we can begin to rediscover Harrison's immense gifts and appreciate them on their own terms. He wrote a lot of beautiful music and it deserves to be heard.

0689859368|2.0|Initially turned off by the similarity in binding to the Lemony Snicket series, I decided it was unfair to blame the author for the marketing department's attempt to copy a good thing, so I bought it.<br />While not completely horrible, it's very, very insignificant.  The illustrations are the best part of it, and the story has so many of them, and so few words, that it's more a picture book than a novel (or part of a novel), despite its tone being a little mature for those for whom a picture book would be appropriate.<br />Essentially nothing happens, which would be all right if it didn't happen in an entertaining and well-written manner, but I'm sorry, in this case things fail to happen in a pedestrian way.<br />It seems that magical beings may be in-and-or-around the new home of our three undeveloped (save for character tics--one fences, one collects animals) main characters.  When they finally meet one near the end of the volume (you knew this would happen eventually, but the characters shouldn't be as knowing) they react with such little surprise, such lack of wonder, that any residual hope I had for the story quite withered away.<br />(I read the second one and though slightly more filled with incident, it was no better written.)<br />For weird houses with secrets, turn to John Bellairs.  For encounters with strange magical creatures, go to E. Nesbit, or one of dozens of others much, much more enjoyable.<br />Note: a 3 star ranking from me is actually pretty good; I reserve 4 stars for tremendously good works, and 5 only for the rare few that are or ought to be classic; unfortunately most books published are 2 or less.

0385504209|1.0|Renowned author Dan Brown watched with justifiable pride as the printer spat forth the final page of his just-completed manuscript.  He smiled wanly with smug satisfaction, knowing that he had successfully butchered theology, history, a score of other academic disciplines and English syntax like a slaughterhouse with a new McDonald's contract.  As he encased the freshly printed manuscript in regulation-brown post-office wrapping paper, Dan couldn't help but notice that it was as thick as three stubbed-out Gitanes laid end-to-end.  How could anyone smoke Gitanes, those practically toxic cigarettes you can mercifully find only in France? Dan thought.  He shook his head in disbelief, then deftly placed the return address sticker on the package.  By now his obviously fertile imagination was doing cartwheels, and he could already see the lightly fluttering bosoms of female talk-show hostesses earnestly inquiring how such a young man could have such deep knowledge of so many profound subjects.  He silently chuckled to himself as he imagined one or two of them confiding, You can uncover the truth of my sacred feminine anytime.  Dan strode to the curb, thrust the package into the mailbox and raised the bright red metal flag, now standing before him like a miniature Eiffel Tower as monument to a goodly year's worth of sweat, tears and sangre.
B0000C0FJB|3.0|There seems to be basically two different opinions presented forth in terms of the sound quality on Rush in Rio.   Some find the sound excellent, while others beg to differ. Personally, I rarely buy live recordings because I actually do prefer the polished studio product over a live recording. Filled with energy or not, live recordings rarely give me much to get excited about, with perhaps ELP and a precious few others being the exception.<br />On the Rush in Rio CD the crowd &quot;noise&quot; is very apparent. Then again, take a look at the SIZE of the crowd that is at the show! While I do find all the chatter and crowd sounds a tad overwhelming, and yes, even annoying, I do resign to the fact that this IS a LIVE show and one can expect the decision making (when doing the mixing) could go a number of ways. In this case, it seems that the live experience was allowed to be taken to a pronounced if not exagerrated level. And here is essentially where opinions are divided.<br />Some listeners wont mind, some will complain, I find myself somewhere in the middle. Pick your poison. Aside from that, Rush was and still is a tight, talented, intelligent band that has thrilled fans for decades. And fortunately, there is still enough of Rush, and good Rush at that on this 3 CD package. The set list speaks for itself. Take it or leave it.

B00004SU5J|5.0|Whereas the spirit of jazz seems to have been castrated here in the United States, giving birth to all sorts of perverse \\"smooth jazz\\" incarnations, elsewhere in the world - particularly in France, it would seem - jazz is dancing and celebrating life as passionately as ever.<br />St. Germain is a wonderfully delicious mix of house beats and jazz improvisation; rather than rehash old jazz tunes and subject them to an electronica-plastered martyrdom, St. Germain - Ludovic Navarre and company - use live instrumentation for their creative and intoxicating mix.  A little Latin groove here, some hip-hop and r&b there, a driving house beat and downright manic solos all fit together to remind us of what it is that jazz is supposed to be.<br />This is one of the few CDs that I own that really seems to cross over and through the various genre gaps; it is smooth - that is, sexy and classy (without being pretentious) at the same time - but also has an excess of pizazz that keeps the listener engaged and flowing.  Such genre-bending both subverts and converts jazz as it has been and propells it into a potential future-made-present; the rumors of a better sound are heard here as a whisper expressed in symphonic song.<br />Perhaps[?] oddly enough, everyone that I have ever played this CD for - whether a 19 year-old Marine, a banker in her mid-40s, or college students that prefer rap and its various metal cross-breeds - liked it.  While I doubt world peace will begin with bringing the people together to listen to St. Germain's \\"Tourist\\", at the same time there really is something ... beautiful about so many different people being able to listen to and appreciate the same music.  It whispers something of the beauty within human subjects.<br />This is a really, really great CD; 5 stars does not do it justice as it is in a class of its own, far beyond the all-too-quantitative measurement of 5 stars.  It breathes spirit and creativity - the best that music as expression and imaginationhas to offer.  Paint your canvas with some passionate new colors; bring the diaspora of your friends together...

B00005B36H|5.0|Once in a while, an album is produced that takes talent and technology and fuses them together in a product that is beyond compare.  Pink Floyd's Dark Side Of The Moon and Prodgy's Fat Of The Land are two good examples; there is no mistaking the genius of the writing, but the production so amplifies it that the final product is more than just the music and the lyrics.  Tool embodies this phenomenon, and as is the hallmark of true art, it is not for the faint at heart.  This is advanced-stage listening; it requires real musical understanding to grasp the brilliance of Danny Carey's drumming, the subtleties of Adam Jones' guitar, the mystery of Justin Chancellor's bass.  Maynard James Keenan's voice is how Tool (and Perfect Circle) becomes accessible to the masses numbed by the Hip-Hop Anti-Musical Revolution,  but it also ties together the most progressive and intelligent music written yet.  &quot;Schism&quot;, common on today's non-corporate radio station airwaves, is but a scratch of the surface.  &quot;Lateralis&quot; may feature the most brilliant ending written to date (just besting Boston's &quot;Don't Look Back&quot; in 1978), but for a real treat, examine the wordless &quot;Triad&quot; on track 12 (similarity: the penultimate song of Prodigy's masterpiece was &quot;Climbatize&quot;, also wordless).  This is an album meant to be experienced with eyes closed, earphones turned up loud, no distractions.  Music as the forefront of art, a shining example of why we turned to notes and rhythms in the first place, and what they can really do to our souls.
B000002J1S|5.0|I have been listening to this album for almost 3 years, and each time I listen to it, it gets better and better. When I first listened to it, I thought it was alright, but I knew it had potential to get better. In my opinion, it is the greatest concept album of all time, and possibly the best album period!!!
B00009Z576|5.0|Pay no mind to the first post that suggests this album isn't a Yes album save for a Roger Dean cover.  <br />If Mr. Chris Squire says it's Yes - and he's the only guy to have been in ALL lineups with the Yes name - then it's Yes.  And guess what, folks?  The album SOUNDS like Yes.  With Howe, Squire and White providing the base - gee, go figure!<br />&quot;Drama&quot; REALLY benefits from an infusion of youth in Geoff Downes, who brought fresh thinking and hi-tech keyboard gear and sounds to the band.  It was also nice to not have a Yes album with the refrigerator magnet lyrical musings of Jon Anderson.  Would I like to hear Jon sing the &quot;Drama&quot; material?  Yep, that'd be nice.  But, I don't have any problems with Mssr. Horn at the mic.<br />You'll get all sorts of styles here - heavy rock (well, for Yes anyway), moody passages, movie muisc (White Car), and more.  <br />For those who want to see how Asia evolved and, to a lesser extent, how Yes moved from the lumbering troupe of the late 70's to the lean machine heard on 90125, this is your album.  One of my all-time favorites.

I think it's a really solid album.  There are some light tracks like Papillion and a Drop in the Ocean that I do really kind of like now, that I wasn't too impressed with back in the day.  <br />Really, now there are a few things I still don't like about it, not really huge problems that would stop me from making any other Stratovarius purchases.  The lyricist seems to like to jam the &quot;I don't believe in god, I believe iin myself and only myself&quot; crap down our throats.  It's ok to have those beliefs and even write some tunes about it, but it's really a bit too much at times.  Please expand your lyrical horizons!  And i'm not too impressed with the really light interlude in Fantasia.  It seems a little out of place, then the mood completely changes with no transition from what sounds like a balad to an early metallica thrash-fest!  Without any sort of transtition!  <br />Well...those small beefs aside, this is a really solid somewhat lighter power metal album that may need a few listens to fully love and appreciate.
B000078DOI|5.0|When I started playing guitar in 1987, I pigeon-holed myself into one playing one type of music or the other. When I first heard this album, I didn't understand it. After 2 days of making myself listen to it, my musical interests expanded ten-fold and by the end of the week, I was listening to everything I could get my hands on. This album helped me explore music as a whole instead of categorically eliminating entire genres of music just because they weren't easily accessible. This album really got me into funk, hard rock, and general weirdness. My album collection expanded to include everything from ABBA to Frank Zappa. I can honestly say that because of Mother's Milk, I am more of a well-rounded musician today instead of a three chord chugging moron. This album introduced me to John Frusciante, and my guitar playing went from being a hobby to a passion. Thanks, John!<BR>If you already own the original version of Mother's Milk, it is not a necessity to own this (the extra tracks don't make it any better or any less incredible), but I gave it five stars because to give it less would be criminal.

B000069AUI|5.0|Cold Play resists the temptation to be all things to all people in this CD, opting instead for a unique sound.  To all those groups that have to force an evocative response, typically signaled by the electric blur of the lead guitar as if to say &quot;here's the part where you're really supposed to feel moved,&quot;  Cold Play consistently manages to move the listener to new dimensions through its artful use of every element in its arsenal.  The piano's smooth weave, the occassional falsetto in the vocals, drums that find their groove..this is a sophisticated sound. A hypnotic work. A Rush lures you in and takes hold, gripping your focus as only fine art across the spectrum of arts is capable of doing.
B00007GZR5|5.0|This movie is like none other.  It's more of a work of art than a movie.  Like many great works of art, the meaning is often left up to the viewer.  What's really important here is how the visual aspect of the film makes you feel.  The storyline is secondary, and for good reason.  It's hard to follow for one, what with the timeline jumping back and forth.  For another, it's a journey into the arena of faith and theology with barely a mention of God.  It's basically a hodgepodge of new age/reincarnation belief, psychobabble, and ultraromanticism.  I consider the storyline nothing more than a tool to explore the possibilities of modern technology in moviemaking.  In this regard this movie excels.  An incredibly vivid imagination and adventurist spirit on the part of those who created this movie brought it from a 20 year old script to the finished product - a cinematic impressionist masterpiece.  (Much of the artwork was actually taken from the works of Van Gogh and Monet.)  This and the additional features provided on the DVD (an excellent mini-documentary on the making of the movie plus a couple of trailers and bios of castmembers and more) give it 5 stars.  If you can actually get anything out of the story that's a bonus.

B000002UJQ|5.0|Let me start by saying that my favorite genres are hiphop, soul, R&amp;B, jazz, funk, gospel. I hate contemporary rock, which mostly sounds like a bunch of bourgeois white boys lamenting about how their pampered life sucks. Never liked Nirvana, or any other &quot;progressive rock&quot; bands. I scoffed when I heard my friends playing Radiohead years back. But it grew on me fast.<br />I've listened to OK Computer countless times, and it's a masterpiece, whether you're into the genre or not. Although some of the lyrics strike a chord with me, by and far most of the words on the tracks fly over my head, consistent with its airy and out-worldly vibe. Sounds like it's trying to be Avant Garde for the sake of being Avant Garde at times.<br />That all doesn't matter when listening to the musical prowess that the band manifests. Radiohead somehow combines grating dissonant sounds into impassioned crescendos that all come together, resolving into a harmony that can only be described as genuis. Distortion guitars and high-pitched sounds characteristic of rock bands these days can drive one up the wall, but Radiohead masterfully fits it all together into tracks that are both melodic and engaging. It still baffles me how such individually unpalatable sounds can sound so good.<br />The stroke of genius doesn't stop at one or two radio-friendly tracks, as a lot of pop bands do with albums (make a hit single, make 10 filler songs). The whole album is great, and tracks seem to naturally progress in a way that you can feel shortchanged if you don't listen to the whole album through each time.<br />Their later albums are just uncomprehendable (Kid A, Hail to the Thief) to me, but after years of listening to this album, I still can regularly put on OK Computer. It ecclectically sits next to my collection of Isley Brothers, D'Angelo, Coltrane and Erkah Badu, testament to the talent that can be appreciated by anyone who appreciates music.

B000007MVM|4.0|It's a shame that more people don't know who this man is. He started one of the biggest rock and roll franchises of the seventies, and even today he is revered in circles of musicians that are educated on the history of Pink Floyd. This album shows his songcrafting abilities and his undeniable guitar skills. Even under a haze of LSD, the man can deliver a song as good as anything that was on the radio back in the day, but his reputation preceded him and his music remains in obscurity. <BR>This isn't a Pink Floyd album. It's full of little ditties about being lost in the woods, girls that don't like his songs, and dresses. The whole album has a &quot;sit right here, I'm gonna play you a song&quot; vibe to it, and the lack of a dedicated backing band makes it almost folky...but those are the qualities that I like about it. It's a little disjointed at times, but an unpolished gem is still a gem.

B00005JMJ4|5.0|This is a truely memorable movie.<br />There seems to be some talk about it being racist against japanese. <br />I would take fault with that... its not about American/English superiority over Japanese, its about the incredible feeling of lonelyness you feel when you're thrust into another culture, for purposes other then pleasure. If anyone has been on a work trip to Mexico, France, Japan or Germany, or if you're not from an English country, taking a business trip to the USA is the same. <br />The scenes with the shower, the evelvator, the directors ... these scenes to me don't laugh at being japanese, they're about how these differences are obsticals that Bob just doesn't have the energy to deal with.<br />When you're on business in another culture, there's just nothing to do when you're just too tired from work to handle the translation, miss-communication or even the TV that you can't understand, the Radio that only plays a few songs you know. If you want to try to feel like it, go home tonight and after the long drive, turn on a TV channel you can't understand, find youself a magazine that's not in your language, sit by yourself on the bed, doing/reading/listening/watching nothing, see how long you last. For myself and people I know, you end up staying entirely in the hotel bar talking to the only waiter that speaks english. <br />This movie shows that the only time Bob and Charlotte ever get to enjoy being in Japan is when they're together. When they have someone to joke with (even share the bad dirty joke), to play with and to talk with. Its only then can you deal with bridging the communication gap. The scenes with their night out in Tokyo together show this perfectly. Just having someone to go back to, share what you've learned, talk about what was weird, what was great, that is what's important. <br />This is a movie about context, its about how powerful cultural context can be, how much we desire to be with someone, anyone that we can relate to. <br />Finally, this is also a movie about the agony boredom, so be be surprised if there's some boring bits.

B00007FOMP|5.0|This is not &quot;merely&quot; a great album - it's the best album of all time! When all the wise foolish critics get together and scribe out their &quot;best of&quot; lists, this is where they (and everyone else) must start. Marvin Gaye was a phenomenally talented singer with a long history of family strife, addiction, abuse and even laziness, self-doubt and procrastination. He had tasted success previously (most notably with &quot;I heard it through the grapevine&quot;) and not only was a member of the famous Motown stable, but he  married in to the Gordy family (yeah, how inscure was he anyways?). But this album immediately put him in a class by himself, beyond reach of the Stones and Beatles and Beach Boys of the pop world and the Aretha Franklin's and Otis Reddings and Stevie Wonders from the soul/R&amp;B side. Did he know what he was doing or was it a happy accident? No one will know for sure, except that this suite of songs changed forever what music would be and shattered people's expectations of what an album could be. The topics aren't fluffy and cute (Sergeant Pepper) or ultimately useless (Who's Next), but they hit hard and home. Poverty? Drug addiction? Government Spending (or overspending, to be more specific)? Child abuse? Religious confusion? It's all there.<br />Any artist coming out with a release after 1971 knew in the back of their mind that they would forever be compared with the bench mark of &quot;What's Going On&quot;. If you're Milli Vanilli and out to make money, great. If you're Smashing Pumpkins and you want to be a critical smash (in addition to the money), great. Whatever and whoever you are, you're going to be measured by this album. It's almost comical (tragicomical) when artists such as Whitney Houston will have the audacity to compare their work with this one. Can you really call any single album number one? No and yes. No, you can only group them with a top 20 of best works, and yes, there is one exception: &quot;What's Going On&quot;.<br />The problem with topical is you can only go so far with it: we are forever a world of indulgence, and that said, we need music, nice hummable melodies that if possible fill our souls with emotions. The end result of lyrics, melodies, performances and productions should be that they take you another, better place. This is exactly what &quot;What's Going On&quot; accomplishes. To pin a historical analogy on it, when you listen to &quot;what's Going On&quot;, consumers can finally have their cake and eat it too.
0385335482|4.0|Sophie Kinsella's 'Confessions of a Shopaholic' is truly a refreshing, entertaining and light-hearted read. The main character Rebecca (Becky) Bloomwood is a 25 year old financial journalist who is in debt because of her frivoulous spending habits. The way Becky gets herself into deeper debt and more trouble is what makes this book so funny. I found that I could not put the book down because I just HAD to see how she was going to get herself out of the sticky situations she managed to get herself in. At times I would get annoyed with some things that Becky did, but I just couldn't stay mad at her. She is like a zany best friend. Her thoughts and the way she  plotted things out were so comical, I found myself literally laughing out loud. This book truly kept my interest throughout. The farther you get into the book, the crazier the circumstances and the louder the laughs. I definatly recommend this book to anyone who is looking for a fun and light read. Thumbs up to Ms. Kinsella!

B00005JMJ4|4.0|Man, another movie that leaves audiences completely divided. Well, I had wanted to see this from the get-go, and though a friend (whose opinion I normally trust) said it didn't live up to his expectations, I personally disagree. <br />It is possible that if you've never immersed yourself in another culture, then you might dislike this film for a variety of reasons; you might have the knee-jerk reaction \\"well, I never wanna go to Japan!\\", but Lost In Translation is not a travel guide for the casual tourist. The characters in the movies are not tourists either. Bill Murray's Bob Harris is in Tokyo to do a TV commercial, and Scarlett Johansson's Charlotte is along for the ride with her working photographer hubby (played by Giovanni Ribisi). These two people are \\"lost\\" and confused in a world that they didn't choose to discover, so don't expect the camera to focus on the aspects of Japanese culture and history that might actually fascinate you. <br />So, we've got Bill Murray - another excellent understated performance (restrained in the same way as his role was in RUSHMORE) - and Scarlett Johansson (who I liked in the otherwise boring HORSE WHISPERER), and they meet in a hotel bar and develop an affinity for one another. Though it's a matter of interpretation, I don't think a romantic relationship really does or is supposed to develop between the two, still, if you are so inclined you can read into their interactions in whatever way you want. I've been the foreigner on many an occasion in another country/culture, and I can confirm that in moments of boredom and perhaps confusion it was a relief meeting a person who was in the same boat as me. Does that mean I have to fall in love and sleep with them just because they can relate to my situation? Come on, that's silly.  <br />I liked the acting, the look, the subtlety of details, and I liked the humour - which doesn't manifest itself in the usual Hollywood Ha-Ha kind of way. Also, the humour is not constant; the latter part of the movie is not nearly as amusing as the classic Murray reactionary humour of the first half, so please, don't expect the \\"Best Comedy of the Year\\". It's not that kind of movie. <br />I read a lot of reviews when the movie was released of people who struggled with the ending calling it 'sad', 'cheap', 'inappropriate', 'unfulfilling' etc. Hmm. I don't know what they were expecting. Let's just say there is no real 'ending' in the traditional movie sense. The final exchange between Bob and Charlotte is left open-ended. I, for one, thought it was the perfect ending. Anything more dramatic would have felt out of place. And besides, I was able to fill in the blanks myself. It's nice when movies let the audience do that. <br />Still, despite all my good feelings towards Lost in Translation, there are flaws. Some people liked the music, but there were several moments in my mind, where that damn music gets spread on too thick. Soft and tinkly one minute, loud and annoying the next. What are we trying to communicate here? Any thing at all? The other thing is that Sofia Coppola (the director) lets the camera linger a wee bit too long on some shots. How many times do we have to see Charlotte sitting on her 100th floor high windowsill overlooking the city? We get the picture. <br />Anyway, it's got some flaws, and it's easy to point them out when - as a viewer - you're so used to being given a certain amount of information either visually or verbally. Well, Lost in Translation doesn't fill in all the gaps for you. But it's worth a rental (I bought it), because it doesn't do things by the book, which is a good thing, and lest I forget, Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson are excellent.

0345446798|5.0|A very good read ...<br />The book starts with the premise that people who love dogs have desire to understand dogs ... And McConnell's book guides us down this very special journey without cloying sentimentality but always with heart and kindness ... <br />A dog behaviour book that goes beyond just reciting basic concepts of dominance, leadership within a pack ... and beyond basic operant, praise &amp; treat methods ... McConnell explores and explains the subtleties of dog nature and human nature ... how our 2 species interract and react one with the other ... the building blocks for better understanding between man and dog ...<br />The author explains why dogs do what they do, and just as important, she explains why we behave the way we do ... and how our very differences, both enrich and causes conflict in our relationships with our canine friends ...<br />The chapter titles are descriptive of the author's beliefs ... 'Translating Primate to Canine' ... 'Pack Mates' ... 'The Truth About Dominance' ... 'Patient Dogs and Wise Humans' ...<br />The author's thoughts are clear and easy to follow ... her words a pleasure to read ...<br />While this book is not a training manual, it will compliment any training manual ... filling the bare bones of training with an appreciation &amp; understanding of how and why training methods work (or don't work) and teaches when and how to modify training methods to suit both dog &amp; owner ...<br />Definitely worth a read ...
B00005JMJ4|5.0|I absolutely adore this film.  When I saw &quot;lost in translation&quot; in the theaters a few months back, I couldn't believe the transformation of funnyman Bill Murray into a serious, middle aged man.  The part could not have been played better, or by anyone else.  The story of the film is quite simple, a man (murray) travels over to japan to shoot a couple vodka commericals in hopes of making a decent dollar.  He's married, and yet unsatisfied and doesn't know where to turn.  Enter scarlet johannson, who plays a newleywed that has the same feelings over her own marriage.  Her husband is too transfixed in his photography career that they hardly spend much time together.  It is only a matter of time before the two souls meet and begin to converse on how they are standing.<br />Really a beautiful film, and astonishing to note that it took just under 4 weeks to film.  Sophia Coppola really displayed an amazing effort, directing, writing, and I believe producing the film.  There is no doubt this film belongs in my top 10 favorites, if not the top 5.  Hey, I'm a nice man, maybe I can sneak it into my top 3.  You would have no idea what you are missing if you calmly skip over this film.  The character development is astonishing, the characters know when to be serious, know when comic relief is sorely needed.  One of the few films of 2003 that will leave you with a smile.
038572179X|2.0|This is yet another one of those prize-winning novels selected for discussion by my book group that I probably wouldn't have read on my own (cf. Soul Mountain, Possession, et al). And once again, I fail to be entranced by what seems to drive everyone else bonkers with reading delight. The caveat to this is that it turns out that I read the book with a very different perspective from my fellow book group members. You see, there's a bit of authorial slight of hand at work, and if you notice what's going on, everything in the book takes on a different shade altogether. Now, I wasn't actively looking for any such thing, but I picked up on a few clues (maybe 'cause I read a lot of detective stories?) and made a few assumptions, which ended up being correct in the end. This is in contrast to the seven other people I discussed the book with, who were floored (and delighted) by a revelation made about 2/3 of the way into it.<br />In any event, the story starts in mid-1930s England in the home of a wealthy landed family. The first third slowly sets up a scenario of the prodigal son returning for the weekend. This is a very controlled and precisely structured bit of very old-fashioned writing which feels highly artificial until the weekend starts to unravel when a crude love note gets into the wrong hands. Emotions start to run high and then a terrible crime is committed, creating a moral ambiguity that the rest of the novel revolves around. In the next section we meet one of the characters in the fields of France several years later, as he struggles with two other soldiers to make it to Dunkirk for the great evacuation. This slender section is quite evocative and quite different from those bookending it. The third section takes the reader back across the channel to Blitz-era London, where several other characters from the country weekend train to be nurses. However, amidst all the action (such as it is), the characters all exist in the shadow of that awful weekend, and operate in service of the much larger theme named by the title.<br />This central question is posed by one the characters: &quot;How can a novelist achieve atonement when, with her absolute power of deciding outcomes, she is also God?&quot; Well, this is the point at which you will either laud McEwan for cleverness and precision of plotting that reveal layers within the story, or you will sigh at McEwan for playing too many games with his work in an attempt to present Deep Thoughts. While I can admire McEwan's precise control of style and voice, which he maintains throughout, and the elaborate construction of layers to the book, I certainly wasn't entranced by the central theme or how it propelled the interaction between characters. Perhaps had I read the story without &quot;getting&quot; what McEwan was up to from the start, I would have enjoyed it more, but I didn't. It doesn't help matters that the characters mostly remain period ciphers of the repressed variety, the kind that the comedian Eddie Izzard is so good at spoofing. Finally, the pace... is... glacial-one of the slowest books to unravel I've ever read. All in all, not a book I'd recommend to friends.te in service of the much larger theme named by the title.<br />This central question is posed by one the characters: &quot;How can a novelist achieve atonement when, with her absolute power of deciding outcomes, she is also God?&quot; Well, this is the point at which you will either laud McEwan for cleverness and precision of plotting that reveal layers within the story, or you will sigh at McEwan for playing too many games with his work in an attempt to present Deep Thoughts. While I can admire McEwan's precise control of style and voice, which he maintains throughout, and the elaborate construction of layers to the book, I certainly wasn't entranced by the central theme or how it propelled the interaction between characters. Perhaps had I read the story without &quot;getting&quot; what McEwan was up to from the start, I would have enjoyed it more, but I didn't. It doesn't help matters that the characters mostly remain period ciphers of the repressed variety, the kind that the comedian Eddie Izzard is so good at spoofing. Finally, the pace... is... glacial-one of the slowest books to unravel I've ever read. All in all, not a book I'd recommend to friends.

B000002G7E|4.0|this is without a doubt the most extreme of all 4 of the velvets albums. while not as amazing as the bands debut album, this is still a very influential, and legendary piece of work. the title track is one of the bands classic songs, and probably the first, or one of the first punk songs ever. the gift is a story about a guy who ships himself to his girlfriend who he feels is cheating on him. its pretty strange, not something you'd listen to all the time. lady godivas operation is about an old folk tale, and has a very disturbing ending. here she comes now is a short song, and very melodic, one of the albums best cuts. i heard her call my name is one of the loudest songs ever. its pretty fuzzed up, and lou does some pretty impressive gutiar work in it. sister ray is up there with heroin, wating for hte man, sweet jane, and rock n roll as one of the main pieces of velvet underground music. 17 minutes of guitar noise, and lyrics about sex, drugs, and every other impure thing in the world. lou's lyrics always are amaizng, but they really stand out here as some of his best. if you are new to the velvets, definetly pick up there debut album.if you are pretty into them, and lou solo, get this. its a classic.

B00007G207|5.0|Cinema Paradiso is a definite classic and is a must-watch for any self-respecting film buff.  I first watched this movie (the cut-version) in 1994 on television.  I loved it so much that I watched it frequently on tape thereafter.  I think I've watched it 2 times a year (on average) and that would make it 20 times by now!   <br /> <br />The innocence of childhood, the passion of first loves, the cruel reality of adulthood are all depicted to perfection in the movie.  Its bitter-sweet ending tops the theme of the whole movie off and it never failed to make me tear.  I had so many questions each time after I watched the movie and that in itself, further reinforced the various main themes of the story: lost loves and most importantly, the great sense of regret that is a result of a lifetime filled with multitudes of unanswered questions.  It was incredibly disappointing as I knew I'd never know the answers to all the questions that I had about the film.  I had great pity for Toto as well as he'd never know.  But this was all before I realised that there was an uncut version. <br /> <br />I upgraded to the DVD version sometime ago but never got around to watching it.  I loaned it out to a friend and got it back months later.  I decided to watch it on a particularly boring afternoon.  As I knew the film so well, I realised that there were scenes in the DVD version which I never saw in the 'old' version.  As I watched further, more of such scenes came up.  And it dawned on me that this version could contain some answers to the many questions which I had!  I watched it right to the end and it still made me tear.  But this time, I was touched not by the storyline itself but by the fact that all the questions that I ever had about the film have finally been answered.  A chapter in Toto's life had finally been closed and for myself, it was also like closing a chapter in my own 'cinematic life'.   <br /> <br />I suggest all interested viewers to watch the 'cut' version first,then the 'uncut' version.  It's a wonderful cinematic experience and allows you to understand and fully appreciate the true essence of the film.  The film was previously cut as it was too long.  With the release of the 'uncut' version, it serves to strongly remind the audience of the greatness of cinema, particularly how the same film can invoke such different emotions by the mere act of cutting some scenes.

B00018D44U|3.0|There is no denying that Norah Jones is a talented woman who took the music world by storm with a quiet and elegant release and general approach that seems downright counterintuitive in today's shock and awe marketing campaigns that seek to find a place for largely talent-less &quot;singers.&quot; I became a fan overnight and thought that her debut CD earned 4 stars. Norah's second release &quot;Feels Like Home&quot;, certainly avoids the sophomore jinx, but in my opinion it does not pack the quiet punch of her debut.<br />The Good: The CD starts off very well and opens up with the optimistic and lively &quot;Sunrise&quot;, which ups her country element to a higher degree while not neglecting her jazzy piano. &quot;What Am I To You&quot; is my favorite song on this release may be the liveliest that Norah has ever sounded. The musical arrangement is so bluesy (do I dare say Stevie Ray Vaugh-ish) and filled with vocal passion that it seems like a natural expansion to her repertoire. &quot;Those Sweet Words&quot; has Norah sounding as warm and expressive with her elegant piano playing and strings making it one of her finest songs to date. &quot;Carnival Town&quot; has a k.d. land feel (circa her &quot;Ingenue&quot; release) and I mean this as a complement as it's not a knock off of k.d. and simply represents a nice change of pace for Norah. &quot;Creepin' In&quot; showcases Norah's country roots, and while the song is contagious in parts, most of the pleasure of this song comes from Dolly Parton's strong voice and ear for melody. Norah seems somewhat out of her element but the song works because of Dolly. &quot;Humble Me&quot; starts out with Simon and Garfunkel inspired strings and showcases the best of Nora's warm voice. The song is slow but not sleep-inducing as the lyrics are good and her voice is pure Norah with a touch of Bonnie Raitt thrown in for good measure. In both &quot;The Prettiest Thing&quot; and &quot;Don't Miss You At All&quot; has Norah doing what she does best, which is evoking the feeling of a late night session with her rich voice and piano right in front of her.<br />The Not So Good: Both &quot;In The Morning&quot; just falls flat. &quot;Be Here To Love Me&quot; is much better, but the problem in both is not in Norah's voice but songs, especially the former, that do not go anywhere lyrically or musically. &quot;Toes&quot; sounds very soothing, but it lacks anything that registers a pulse and is truly sleep inducing. Not the worst offense in the world, but I am certain that easing one to sleep is Norah's intent as one would miss the rest of the CD. I am not being flip here. &quot;Above Ground&quot; is dead on arrival, despite some great guitar work. &quot;The Long Way Home&quot; sounds (cheap pun intended) like a long and way too slow way home.<br />In a nutshell, this is a good effort that has Norah sounding less jazzy and more country-tinged than in her first release. The problem here lies in that she greatly reduces the noirish tone that works so well for her before and ups the country-twanged elements (both in her voice and arrangements) and she winds up sounding much less convincing than in her first release as there are many singers who have stronger voices (like Bonnie Raitt and Sheryl Crow) that can bring to life the country elements that stagnate quite a few of the songs. To end on a good note, there is rawness in the production that's refreshing as she allows even a few off-key notes to remain. Also, although it may not look like it to some, this release shows some quiet yet notable experimentation. Not all of it works, but it is always refreshing to hear something that was not created for mass market consumption. What the music industry does not get is that the more they focus on talent over veils, they will wind up selling millions along the way as this release already has. It may sound tough to give this only 3 stars, but I still lean towards recommending it for the points highlighted above.e does best, which is evoking the feeling of a late night session with her rich voice and piano right in front of her.<br />The Not So Good: Both &quot;In The Morning&quot; just falls flat. &quot;Be Here To Love Me&quot; is much better, but the problem in both is not in Norah's voice but songs, especially the former, that do not go anywhere lyrically or musically. &quot;Toes&quot; sounds very soothing, but it lacks anything that registers a pulse and is truly sleep inducing. Not the worst offense in the world, but I am certain that easing one to sleep is Norah's intent as one would miss the rest of the CD. I am not being flip here. &quot;Above Ground&quot; is dead on arrival, despite some great guitar work. &quot;The Long Way Home&quot; sounds (cheap pun intended) like a long and way too slow way home.<br />In a nutshell, this is a good effort that has Norah sounding less jazzy and more country-tinged than in her first release. The problem here lies in that she greatly reduces the noirish tone that works so well for her before and ups the country-twanged elements (both in her voice and arrangements) and she winds up sounding much less convincing than in her first release as there are many singers who have stronger voices (like Bonnie Raitt and Sheryl Crow) that can bring to life the country elements that stagnate quite a few of the songs. To end on a good note, there is rawness in the production that's refreshing as she allows even a few off-key notes to remain. Also, although it may not look like it to some, this release shows some quiet yet notable experimentation. Not all of it works, but it is always refreshing to hear something that was not created for mass market consumption. What the music industry does not get is that the more they focus on talent over veils, they will wind up selling millions along the way as this release already has. It may sound tough to give this only 3 stars, but I still lean towards recommending it for the points highlighted above.

B0001HAISG|5.0|Seeing this movie in the theater was something of a marvel. My wife and I were surrounded by little children, each of which were more excited about this movie than I had seen for Lord of the Rings, or Star Wars, or any major epic in recent years. See this movie was meant for them. We all know and love the story of Peter Pan, and a good many of us also fell in love with the unofficial sequel Hook (albeit only after it hit home video and DVD as its theatrical presentation didn't fare to well.) But it was only after seeing this movie sitting next to a young girl, about 6 or 7 at the most and seeing how she responded to this film did I begin to understand what Peter Pan is. Its a story about the tragedy of loosing our innocence, about being forced to grow up, and take on adult responsibilities when we all would much rather just play and have fun. Most of all its about wanting the best of both worlds, the things that come with adulthood such as love, and family, without having to sacrifice the comforts of childhood. That is the inner struggle of Peter Pan. He wants to love, but knows that he cannot, because if he gives into his heart it means he would have to grow up. It's amazing to see a movie that so beautifully captures the emotional struggle that children go through at that age. The inner struggle to cling to the things that are fun, and innocent, and childish, versus the desire to become independent, to love and be loved beyond a mother-son-brother-father type of setting, and yet the need to be cared for and taken care of. I was blown away by this movie because quite simply... I have never read the book, and I had no idea Peter Pan was this deep. The most moving part was when the girl I was sitting next to cried into her mother's chest proclaiming that she didn't want to grow up. There is the heart of Peter Pan, realizing that inevitably we all grow up, we'll all have bills, we'll all have unsatisfactory jobs (with a few exceptions), we'll all grow old, and most important we'll all die. Peter Pan is a symbol defying this cycle that binds and imprisons all adults. I suddenly find myself wishing I hadn't grown up either. That's not to say that I don't enjoy the benefits of being an adult, but this movie did make me yearn again for my younger days. Without a doubt, this movie is a must see for everyone. Child and adult alike this film will reach you in ways that no other presentation of this story has ever accomplished.portant we'll all die. Peter Pan is a symbol defying this cycle that binds and imprisons all adults. I suddenly find myself wishing I hadn't grown up either. That's not to say that I don't enjoy the benefits of being an adult, but this movie did make me yearn again for my younger days. Without a doubt, this movie is a must see for everyone. Child and adult alike this film will reach you in ways that no other presentation of this story has ever accomplished.

B000003TA4|5.0|This album is definitely a classic, whether you feel it deserves the praise it gets or not, it is as important a milestone in the history of music as any Beatles or Robert Johnson album.<BR>On first hearing this album it is the simple, catchy melodies which draw you in but before long the lyrics become the more prominent feature, at once you recognise what Kurt is trying to say but at the same time the lyrics are somewhat confusing and one is encouraged to meditate on the songs.<BR>In trying to decode the often related metaphors of songs such as Lounge Act you begin to see the world through the Kurt Cobain perspective. Driving these twisted lyrics is Kurt's raw, billiant voice which communicates the feeling's lying beneath  the verse. One hears pain, passion, honesty and joy in his voice. Adding to this is Kurt's thundersous guitar, Dave's percussion and Krist base, all combining to create the distinctive sound of this album. <BR>Every Nirvana song, not just those on Nevermind, possess a part of the soul of Kurt Cobain. We were denied incredibly quickly the chance to hear another, yet are drawn to them forever.
B00018D44U|5.0|Sometimes, sophomore efforts slump, and often they turn out well. Rarely, though, does a second offering hit the perfect chord as Feels Like Home does. <BR>With this album, Norah Jones changes just enough to differentiate from her debut, Come Away With Me, without deconstructing what she does so well - the mellow, soft, serene, piano-based tune. On Feels Like Home, Jones tweaks the instrumentation, adding a base line here and placing some acoustic parts there, and interprets lyrical content that is both unique and relevant. \\"In the Morning\\" contains this line - \\"Funny how my favorite shirt smells more like you than me.\\" \\"Carnival Town\\" offers this thought - \\"Did the clown make you smile? He was only your fool for a while.\\" One of the album's best offerings, the jazzy and poignant \\"The Prettiest Thing,\\" offers this - \\"The prettiest thing I ever did see was lighting from the top of the clouds, moving through the night a million miles an hour with somewhere to go.\\"<br />Feels Like Home is just beautiful, a flawless progression from Come Away With Me. Jones' velvety voice melts into music. Perhaps the most endearing track is \\"Don't Miss You At All.\\" You imagine Jones sitting alone with a piano in some quiet place releasing thoughts and molding melodies without effort.
